abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Pilot Fishery
            Development Project for Albania were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: although assessed as a high risk operation
            at the time of appraisal, due to the conditions prevailing
            at that time it was also viewed as the appropriate approach
            to re-establishing control of the fisheries sector and
            taking first steps toward its sustainable development.
            Project objectives have been largely achieved, and the risky
            strategy has proven to be appropriate. Frequent and
            substantive guidance and support made available by the
            supervision team was instrumental in capturing the benefits
            of this approach. The availability and distribution of
            Government subsidized fuel to fishing vessel owners via the
            Fisheries Management Organizations (FMOs) provided an
            economic incentive for vessel owners to become members, and
            also helped FMOs establish financial self sufficiency. While
            Government and sector stakeholders have achieved significant
            progress in establishing the institutional framework for
            co-management, sustainability of FMOs, their effective
            operation of port facilities, and implementation of fishery
            co-management will require continued leadership and
            strategically targeted support from Government beyond the
            five year life of the project. This should include provision
            of joint training for FMO and fisheries inspectorate staff,
            and collaborative development of operational procedures.

5085405.trustfund: TF038466-ALBANIA:  FISHERY DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF039653-ALBANIA - FISHERY DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF039852-ALBANIA - RURAL DEVELOPMENT,TF026253-PHRD-FISHERY DEVELOPMENT PROJECT
5085405.majtheme: Social dev/gender/inclusion,Environment and natural resource management,Rural development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Pilot Fishery Development Project
            has the main objectives of improving the operation and
            management of fishing ports, introducing an effective
            institutional framework for community-driven co-management
            of marine resources, and restoring the country's
            previous capacity in aquaculture as well as exploring the
            potential for further development of aquaculture,
            particularly for high value species. To achieve these aims,
            the project supports three main components. The first
            component rehabilitates fishing port facilities and supports
            the institutional strengthening of Fishery Management
            Organizations to improve their management of fishing port
            facilities, and to promote self-regulation as the key to
            sustainable marine resource management. To that end, the
            project recruits national coordiantors and regional
            promoters, supplies international technical assistance to
            the FMOs, prepares fishery management plans, develops marine
            ecotourism, and supports training and demonstration
            programs. The second component provides support to restock
            carp in reservoirs, supports the Koran restocking program,
            and pilots a program to test the aquaculture of new marine
            and fresh water species such as tilapia and shrimp. The
            third component finances legal training and assistance for
            preparing technical documents, provides legal assitance to
            support the Fisheries Directorate, supports a fisheries
            management information system, and prepares a business plan
            for the Fishery Research Institute.

repnme.cdata!:
Albania - Pilot Fishery Development Project
            : environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fishery Development Project was
            designed to address the ecological and environmental issues
            arising from over-fishing and the use of destructive and
            unsustainable fishing methods. There are two major project
            activities that may potentially present risks to the
            environmental and ecology: a) the larger-scale aquaculture
            activities for Koran, and high-value marine species; and b)
            construction works for the rehabilitation of the fishing
            ports. The construction of the quays at Shengjin and Saranda
            will entail the loss of both intertidal habitat and bottom
            habitat. The loss will be kept down to bare minimum with
            good construction site management. Pollution of the aquatic
            environment from increased vessel operations may be
            mitigated by setting up waste reception facilities for each
            operation separately. Port facilities will be equipped with
            an oily water separator and suction pump. Special
            receptacles will be provided inside the same port areas for
            the disposal of used engine oil that will then be collected
            by authorized collector for proper disposal. Receptacles
            will also be provided for hazardous solid wastes. Skips or
            enclosed dumping enclosures will be provided for the
            disposal of large objects. Airtight PVC containers will be
            provided in areas where wet fish wastes will be produced.
            Refueling of vessels will be done in accordance with
            internationally accepted standards. Wet wastes and
            polystyrene foam from single-use fish boxes will be disposed
            of by receptacles.
